note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter King Frederick, Sorano, Valerio, Camillo, Cleanthes, Menallo, and Attendants.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: _WIll your Grace ſpeak?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Let me alone Sorano,
Although my thoughts ſeeme ſad, they are welcome to me.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: You know I am private as your ſecret wiſhes,
Ready to fling my ſoule upon your ſervice,
Ere your command be on't.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Bid thoſe depart.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: You muſt retire my Lords.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: What new deſign in hammering in his head now?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Lets pray heartily
None of our heads meet with it, my wife's old,
That's all my comfort.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Mine's ugly, that I am ſure on,
And I think honeſt too, 'twould make me ſtart elſe.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Mine's troubled in the Country with a feaver,
And ſome few infirmities elſe; he looks againe,
Come le'ts retire, certaine 'tis ſome ſhe buſineſſe,
This new Lord is imployed.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I'le not be far off, becauſe I doubt the cauſe. Ex. Lords.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Are they all gone?

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: All but your faithfull ſervant.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I would tell thee,
But 'tis a thing thou canſt not like.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Pray ye ſpeak it, is it my head? I have it ready for ye, Sir:
Is't any action in my powre? my wit?
I care not of what nature, nor what followes.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: I am in love.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: That's the leaſt thing of a thouſand,
The eaſieſt to atchieve.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: But with whom Sorano?

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: With whom you pleaſe, you muſt not be deny'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Say it be with one of thy Kinſwomen.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Say withall,
I ſhall more love your Grace, I ſhall more honour ye,
And would I had enough to ſerve your pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Why 'tis thy Siſter then, the faire Evanthe,
Ile be plaine with thee.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Ile be as plaine with you Sir,
She brought not her perfections to the world,
To lock them in a caſe, or hang 'em by her,
The uſe is all ſhe breeds 'em for, ſhe is yours, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Doſt thou meane ſeriouſly?

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: I meane my Siſter,
And if I had a dozen more, they were all yours:
Some Aunts I have, they have been handſome women,
My mother's dead indeed, and ſome few cozens
That are now ſhooting up, we ſhall ſee ſhortly.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: No, 'tis Evanthe.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: I have ſent my man unto her,
Upon ſome buſineſſe to come preſently
Hither, ſhe ſhall come; Your Grace dare ſpeak unto her?
Large golden promiſes, and ſweet language, Sir,
You know what they worke, ſhe is a compleat Courtier,
Beſides Ile ſet in.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: She weights upon my Queene,
What jealouſie and anger may ariſe,
Incenſing her?

sp.speaker: Sora.
sp.l: You have a good ſweet Lady,
A woman of ſo even and ſtill a temper,
She knows not anger; ſay ſhe were a fury,
I had thought you had been abſolute the great King,
The fountaine of all honours, playes and pleaſures,
Your will and your commands unbounded alſo;
Go get a paire of beads and learne to pray, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: My Lord, your ſervant ſtaies.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Bid him come hither, and bring the Lady with him.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I will wooe her,
And either loſe my ſelfe, or win her favour.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: She is comming in.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Thy eyes ſhoot through the doore,
They are ſo piercing, that the beames they dart
Give new light to the roome.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: Whether doſt thou go?
This is the Kings ſide, and his private lodgings,
What buſineſſe have I here?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.l: My Lord ſent for ye.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: His lodgings are below, you are miſtaken,
We left them at the ſtaire-foot.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.l: Good ſweet Madam,

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: I am no Counſellor, nor important Sutor.
Nor have no private buſineſſe through theſe Chambers,
To ſeek him this way, o' my life thou art drunke,
Or worſe then drunke, hir'd to convey me hither
To ſome baſe end; now I looke on thee better,
Thou haſt a bawdy face, and I abhor thee,
A beaſtly bawdy face, Ile go no further.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Nay ſhrink not back, indeed you ſhall good Siſter,
Why do you bluſh? the good King will not hurt ye,
He honours ye, and loves ye.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: Is this the buſineſſe?

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.p: Yes, and the beſt you ever will arive at, if you be wiſe.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: My Father was no bawd Sir,
Nor of that worſhipfull ſtock as I remember.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: You are a foole.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: You are that I ſhame to tell ye.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Gentle Evanthe.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: The gracious Queen Sir
Is well and merry, heaven be thanked for it,
And as I think ſhe waites you in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Let her wait there, I talk not of her Garden,
I talk of thee ſweet flower.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: Your Grace is pleaſant,
To miſtake a nettle for a roſe.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: No Roſe, nor Lilly, nor no glorious Hyacinth
Are of that ſweetneſſe, whiteneſſe, tenderneſſe,
Softneſſe, and ſatisfying bleſſedneſſe
As my Evanthe.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: Your Grace ſpeakes very feelingly,
I would not be a hanſome wench in your way Sir,
For a new gowne.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Thou art all hanſomneſſe,
Nature will be aſham'd to frame another
Now thou art made, thou haſt rob'd her of her cunning,
Each ſeverall part about thee is a beauty.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Do you heare this Siſter?

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: Yes unworthy Brother, but all this will not do.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: But love Evanthe,
Thou ſhalt have more then words, wealth, eaſe, and honors
My tender wench.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: Be tender of my credit,
And I ſhall love you Sir, and I ſhall honour ye.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I love thee to injoy thee my Evanthe,
To give thee the content of love.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: Hold, hold Sir, ye are to fleet,
I have ſome buſineſſe this way, your Grace can nere con|tent.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: You ſtubborne toy.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: Good my Lord Bawd I thank ye.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt not go, beleeve me ſweet Evanthe,
So high I will advance thee for this favour,
So rich and potent I will raiſe thy fortune,
And thy friends mighty.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: Good your Grace be patient,
I ſhall make the wo●ſt honourable wench that ever was,
Shame your diſcretion, and your choyce.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt not.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: Shall I be rich do you ſay, and glorious,
And ſhine above the reſt, and ſcorne all beauties,
And mighty in command?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt be any thing.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: Let me be honeſt too, and then ile thank ye.
Have you not ſuch a title to beſtow too?
If I prove otherwiſe, I would know but this Sir;
Can all the power you have or all the riches,
But tye mens tongues up from diſcourſing of me,
Their eyes from gazing at my glorious folly,
Time that ſhall come from wondering at my impudence,
And they that read my wanton life from curſes?
Can you do this? have ye this magick in ye?
This is not in your powre, though you be a Prince Sir,
No more then evill is in holy Angels,
Nor I, I hope; get wantonneſſe confirm'd
By Act of Parliament an honeſty,
And ſo receiv'd by all, ile hearken to ye.
Heaven guide your Grace.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Evanthe, ſtay a little,
Ile no more wantonneſſe, ile marry thee.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: What ſhall the Queene do?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Ile be divorſed from her.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: Can you tell why? what has ſhe done againſt ye?
Has ſhe contrived a treaſon gainſt your Perſon?
Abus'd your bed? does diſobedience urge ye?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: That's all one, 'tis my will.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: 'Tis a moſt wicked one,
A moſt abſurd one, and will ſhow a Monſter;
I had rather be a Whore, and with leſſe ſin,
To your preſent luſt, then Queen to your unjuſtice.
Yours is no love, Faith and Religion fly it,
Nor has no taſte of faire affection in it,
Some helliſh flame abuſes your faire body,
And helliſh furies blow it; looke behinde ye,
Divorſe ye from a woman of her beauty,
Of her integrity, her piety?
Her love to you, to all that honours ye,
Her chaſt and vertuous love, are theſe fit cauſes?
What will you do to me, when I have cloyd ye?
You may finde time out in eternity,
Deceit and violence in heavenly Juſtice,
Life in the grave, and death among the bleſſed,
Ere ſtaine or brack in her ſweet reputation.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: You have fool'd enough, be wiſe now, and a wo|man,
You have ſhew'd a modeſty ſufficient,
If not too much for Court.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: You have ſhew'd an impudence,
A more experienc'd bawd would bluſh and ſhake at;
You will make my kindred mighty.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Prethee heare me.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: I do Sir, and I count it a great offer.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Any of thine.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: 'Tis like enough you may clap honour on them,
But how 'twill ſit, and how men will adore it,
Is ſtill the queſtion. Ile tell you what they'l ſay Sir,
What the report will be, and 'twill be true too,
And it muſt needs be comfort to your Maſter,
Theſe are the iſſues of her impudence:
Ile tell your Grace, ſo deare I hold the Queene,
So deare that honour that ſhe nurs'd me up in,
I would firſt take to me, for my luſt, a Moore,
One of your Gally-ſlaves, that cold and hunger,
Decrepid miſery, had made a mock-man,
Then be your Queene.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: You are bravely reſolute.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: I had rather be a Leopar, and be ſhun'd,
And dye by peeces, rot into my grave,
Leaving no memory behind to know me,
Then be a high Whore to eternity.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: You have another Gamſter I perceive by ye,
You durſt not ſlight me elſe.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Ile finde him out,
Though he lye next thy heart hid, Ile diſcover him,
And ye proud peat, Ile make you curſe your inſolence.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Tongue of an Angell, and the truth of Heaven,
How am I bleſt? Exit Val.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Podramo go in haſt
To my Siſters Gentlewoman, you know her well,
And bid her ſend her Miſtris preſently
The leſſer Cabinet ſhe keeps her Letters in,
And ſuch like toyes, and bring it to me Inſtantly. Away.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.l: I am gone. Exit.

div.stage: Enter the Queene with two Ladies.

sp.speaker: Sora.
sp.l: The Queene.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Lets quit the place, ſhe may grow jealous. Exit Fred. Soran.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: So ſuddenly departed, what's the reaſon?
Doe's my approach diſpleaſe his Grace? are my eyes
So hatefull to him? or my converſation
Infected, that he flies me? faire Evanthe,
Are you there? then I ſee his ſhame.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: 'Tis true Madam,
'Thas pleas'd his Goodneſſe to be pleaſant with me,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis ſtrange to finde thy modeſty in this place,
Doe's the King offer faire? doe's thy face take him?
Nere bluſh Evanthe, 'tis a very ſweet one,
Doe's he raine gold, and precious promiſes
Into thy lap? will he advance thy fortunes?
Shalt thou be mighty wench?

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Never mock Madam;
'Tis rather on your part to be lamented,
At leaſt reveng'd, I can be mighty Lady,
And glorious too, glorious and great, as you are.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He will marry thee.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Who would not be a Queene, Madam?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis true Evanthe, 'tis a brave ambition,
A golden dreame, that may delude a good minde,
What ſhall become of me?

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: You muſt learne to pray,
Your age and honour will become a Nunnery.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Wilt thou remember me? Weeps.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: She weeps. Sweet Lady
Upon my knees I aske your ſacred pardon,
For my rude boldneſſe; and know, my ſweet Miſtris,
If e're there were ambition in Evanthe,
It was and is to do you faithfull duties;
'Tis true I have been tempted by the King,
And with no few and potent charmes, to wrong ye,
To violate the chaſte joyes of your bed;
And thoſe not taking hold, to uſurpe your ſtate,
But ſhe that has been bred up under ye,
And daily fed upon your vertuous precepts,
Still growing ſtrong by example of your goodneſſe,
Having no errant motion from obedience,
Flyes from theſe vanities, as meere illuſions;
And arm'd with honeſty, defies all promiſes.
In token of this truth, I lay my life downe
Under your ſacred foot, to do you ſervice.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Riſe my true friend, thou vertuous, bud of beauty,
Thou Virgins honour, ſweetly blow and flouriſh,
And that rude nipping winde, that ſeeks to blaſt thee,
Or taint thy root, be curſt to all poſterity;
To my pro●ection from this houre I take ye,
Yes, and the King ſhall know—

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Give his heat way, Madam,
And 'twill go out againe, he may forget all. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: What have we to do with the times? we cannot cure 'em;
Let 'em go on, when they are ſwolne with ſurfets
They'le burſt and ſtink, then all the world ſhall ſmell 'em

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: A man may live a bawd, and be an honeſt man.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Yes, and a wiſe man too, 'tis a vertuous calling.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: To his owne wife eſpecially, or to his ſiſter,
The neerer to his owne blood, ſtill the honeſter;
There want ſuch honeſt men, would we had more of 'em.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: To be a villaine is no ſuch rude matter.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: No, if he be a neat one, and a perfect,
Art makes all excellent, what is it Gentl.
In a good cauſe to kill a dozen coxcombs?
That blunt rude fellowes call good Patriots?
Nothing, nor ne're look'd after.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: 'Tis ene as much, as eaſie too, as honeſt, & as cleer,
To raviſh Matrons, and deflowre coy wenches,
But here they are ſo willing, 'tis a complement.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: To pull downe Churches with pretention,
To build 'em fairer, may be done with honour,
And all this time beleeve no God.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I think ſo, 'tis faith enough if they name him in their angers,
Or on their rotten Tombs ingrave an Angell;
Well, brave Alphonſo, how happy had we been,
If thou had'ſt rain'd?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Would I had his diſeaſe,
Tyed like a Leproſie to my poſterity,
So he were right againe.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: What is his Melady?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Nothing but ſad and ſilent melancholly,
Laden with griefes and thoughts, no man knows why neither;
The good Brandino Father to the Princeſſe,
Uſed all the art and induſtry that might be,
To free Alphonſo from this dull calamity,
And ſeat him in his rule, he was his eldeſt
And nobleſt too, had not faire nature ſtopt in him,
For which cauſe this was choſen to inherit,
Frederick the yonger.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Doe's he uſe his brother
With that reſpect and honour that befits him?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: He is kept privately, as they pretend,
To give more eaſe and comfort to his ſickneſſe;
But he has honeſt ſervants, the grave Rugio,
And Fryer Marco, that waight upon his Perſon,
And in a Monaſtery he lives.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: 'Tis full of ſadneſſe,
To ſee him when he comes to his fathers Tombe,
As once a day that is his Pilgrimage,
Whilſt in devotion the Quire ſings an Antheme:
How piouſly he kneeles, and like a Virgin
That ſome croſſe fate had cozen'd of her Love,
Weeps till the ſtubborne Marble ſweats with pitty,
And to his grones the whole Quire beares a Chorus.

div.stage: Enter Frederick, Sorano with the Cabinet.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.l: So do I too. The King with his contrivers,
This is no place for us. Exeunt Lords.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: This is a Jewell,
Lay it aſide, what Paper's that?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.l: A Letter,
But 'tis a womans, Sir, I know by the hand,
And the falſe authography, they write old Saxon.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: May be her ghoſtly mothers, that inſtructs her.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: No, 'tis a cozens, and came up with a great Cake.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Sora.
sp.l: A paire of Gloves the Ducheſſe gave her,
For ſo the outſide ſaies:

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: That other Paper?

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.p: A charme for the tooth-ach, here's nothing but Saints and Croſſes.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Look in that box, me thinks that ſhould hold ſecrets,

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.l: 'Tis paint and curles of haire, ſhe begins to exerciſe.
A glaſſe of water too, I would faine taſte it,
But I am wickedly afraid 'twill ſilence me,
Never a Conduit Pipe to convey this water.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Theſe are all Rings, deaths heads, and ſuch me||mentoe●
Her Grandmother, and worme-eaten Aunts left to her,
To tell her what her beauty muſt arive at.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: That, that.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.l: They are written Songs Sir, to provoke young Ladies;
Lords, here's a prayer booke, how theſe agree?
Here's a ſtrange Union.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.p: Ever by a ſafeſt you have a julip ſet to coole the Patient.

sp.speaker: Fred
sp.l: Thoſe, thoſe.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: They are Verſes to the bleſt Evanthe.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Thoſe may diſcover,
Reade them out Sorant.

body.l: LEt thoſe complaine, that feeles Loves cruelty,
And in ſad Legents write their woes,
My war is without rage or blowes;
My Miſtris eyes ſhine faire on my deſires,
And hope ſprings up inflam'd with her new fires.
No more an Exile will I dwell,
With folded armes, and ſighs all day,
Reckoning the torments of my hell,
And flinging my ſweet joyes away;
I am call'd home againe to quiet peace,
My Miſtris ſmiles, and all my ſorrowes ceaſe.
Yet what is living in her eyes?
Or being bleſt with her ſweet tongue,
If theſe no other joyes imply?
A golden Give, a pleaſing wrong:
To be your owne but one poore Moneth, I'd give
My youth, my fortune, and then leave to live.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: This is my rivall, that I knew the hand now.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: I know it, I have ſeene it, 'tis Valerio's,
That hopefull Gentlemans that was brought up with ye,
And by your charge nouriſht and fed
At the ſame Table, with the ſame allowance.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: And all this curteſie to ruine me?
Croſſe my deſires? had better have fed humblier,
And ſtood at greater diſtance from my fury:
Go for him quickly, finde him inſtantly,
Whilſt my impatient heart ſwells high with choller;
Better have lov'd deſpaire, and ſafer kiſt her. Exit Lords.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: Thou old weak foole, doſt thou know to what end,
To what betraying end he got this Casket?
Durſt thou deliver him without my Ring?
Or a command from mine own mouth? that Cabinet
That holds my heart, you unconſiderate aſſe,
Thou brainleſſe Ideot.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.l: I ſaw you go with him,
At their firſt word commit your perſon to him,
And made no ſcruple; he is your brothers Gentleman,
And for any thing I know, an honeſt man;
And might not I upon the ſame ſecurity deliver him a box?

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: A Bottle-head.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: You ſhall have cauſe to chafe, as I will handle it.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: I had rather thou hadſt delivered me to Pirats,
Betraid me to uncurable diſeaſes,
Hung up my Picture in a Market place,
And ſold me to wilde bawds.

sp.speaker: Caſſan.
sp.l: As I take it Madam,
Your Maidenhead lyes not in that Cabinet,
You have a Cloſer, and you keep the key too,
Why are you vext thus?

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: I could curſe thee wickedly,
And wiſh thee more deformed then age can make thee,
Perpetuall hunger, and no teeth to ſatisfie it,
Waight on thee ſtill, nor ſleep be found to eaſe it:
Thoſe hands that gave the Casket, may the Palfie
For ever make unuſefull, even to feed thee;
Long winters, that thy bones may turne to Iſicles
No Hell can thaw againe, inhabit by thee.
Is thy care like thy body, all on crookedneſſe?
How ſcurvily thou crieſt now? like a drunkard,
Ile have as pure teares from a durty ſpout:
Do, ſweare thou didſt this ignorantly, ſweare it,
Sweare and be damn'd, thou halfe witch.

sp.speaker: Caſſan.
sp.l: Theſe are fine words, well Madam, Madam.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: 'Tis not well thou mummy,
'Tis impudently, baſely done, thou durty—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Has your young ſanctity done railing, Madam,
Againſt your innocent Squire? do you ſee this Sonnet?
This loving Script? do you know from whence it came too?

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: I do, and dare avouch it pure and honeſt.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: You have private Viſitants, my noble Lady,
That in ſweet numbers court your goodly vertues,
And to the height of adoration.

sp.speaker: Evan,
sp.l: Well Sir,
There's neither Hereſie nor Treaſon in it.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: A Prince may beg at the doore; whilſt theſe feaſt with ye;
A favour or a grace, from ſuch as I am.
Courſe, common things. You are welcome; pray come neer, Sir,
Do you know this paper?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I am betray'd; I do Sir,
'Tis mine, my hand and heart, if I die for her,
I am thy Martyr, Love, and time ſhall honour me.

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.l: You ſawcy Sir, that came in my Ladies name,
For her guilt Cabinet, you cheating Sir too,
You ſcurvy Uſher, with as ſcurvy leggs,
And a worſe face, thou poore baſe hanging holder,
How durſt thou come to me with a lye in thy mouth?
An impudent lye?

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.l: Hollow, good Jill, you hobble.

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.l: A ſtinking lye, more ſtinking then the teller,
To play the pilfring knave, there have been raſcals
Brought up to fetch and carry like your Worſhip,
That have been hang'd for leſſe, whipt there are daily
And if the Law will do me right—

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.l: What then old Maggot?

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.l: Thy mother was carted younger; Ile have thy hide,
Thy mangy hide, embroder'd with a dog-whip,
As it is now with potent Pox, and thicker.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Peace, good antiquity, Ile have your bones elſe
Ground into Gunpowder to ſhoot at Cats with;
One word more, and Ile blanch thee like an Almond,
There's no ſuch cure for the ſhe-falling-ſickneſſe,
As the powder of a dried bawds skin, be ſilent,
You are very prodigall of your ſervice here, Sir,
Of your life more it ſeems.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I repent neither,
Becauſe Your Grace ſhall underſtand it comes
From the beſt part of love, my pure affection,
And kindled with chaſte flame, I will not fly from it,
If it be error to deſire to marry,
And marry her that ſanctity would dote on,
I have done amiſſe; if it be a Treaſon
To graft my ſoule to vertue, and to grow there,
To love the tree that beares ſuch happineſſe;
Conceive me, Sir, this fruit was ne're forbidden;
Nay, to deſire to taſte too, I am Traytor;
Had you but plants enough of this bleſt Tree, Sir,
Set round about your Court to beautifie it,
Deaths twice ſo many, to diſmay the aproachers,
The ground would ſcarce yeeld graves to noble Lovers,

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis well maintain'd, you wiſh and pray to fortune,
Here in your Sonnet, and ſhe has heard your prayers,
So much you dote upon your owne undoing,
But one Month to injoy her as your wife,
Though at the expiring of that time you die for't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I could wiſh many, many ages Sir,
To grow as old as time in her imbraces,
If heaven would grant it, and you ſmile upon it;
But if my choice were two houres, and then periſh,
I would not pull my heart back.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: You have your wiſh,
To'morrow I will ſee you nobly married,
Your Month take out in all content and pleaſure;
The firſt day of the following Month you dye for't;
Kneele, not, not all your prayers can divert me;
Now marke your ſentence, mark it ſcornfull Lady,
If when Valerio's dead, within twelve houres,
For thar's your lateſt time, you finde not out
Another husband on the ſame condition
To marry you againe, you dye your ſelf too.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Now you are mercifull, I thank your Grace.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: If when you are married, you but ſeek to ſcape
Out of the Kingdome, you, or ſhe, or both,
Or to infect mens minds with hot commotions,
You dye both inſtantly; will you love me now Lady?
My tale will now be heard, but now I ſcorne ye. Exe.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: Is our faire love, our honeſt, our intire,
Come to this hazard?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Tis a noble one, and I am much in love with malice for it,
Envy could not have ſtudied me a way,
Nor fortune pointed out a path to honour,
Straighter and nobler, if ſhe had her eyes:
When I have once injoyed my ſweet Evanthe,
And bleſt my youth with her moſt deere Imbraces,
I have done my journey here, my day is out,
All that the world has elſe is foolery,
Labour, and loſſe of time, what ſhould I live for?
Think but mans life a moneth, and we are happy.
I would not have my joyes grow old for any thing;
A paradiſe, as thou art my Evanthe,
Is only made to wonder at a little,
Enough for humane eyes, and then to wander from.
Come do not weep, ſweet, you diſhonour me,
Your teares and griefes but queſtion my ability,
Whether I dare dye: Do you love intirely?

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: You know I do.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Then grudge not my felicity.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: Ile to the Queene.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Do any thing that's honeſt,
But if you ſue to him in death, I hate you.

div.head: Scaena Prima.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: WAs there ever heard of ſuch a marriage?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Marriage and hanging go by deſtiny,
'Tis the old proverb, now they come together.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: But a month married, then to loſe his life for't?
I would have a long month ſure that payes the Souldiers,

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Or get all the Almanacks burnt, that were a rare trick,
And have no month remembred. How now Tony?
Whoſe water are you caſting?

sp.speaker: Tony.
sp.l: A ſick Gentlemans,
Is very ſick, much troubled with the ſtone,
He ſhould not live above a month by his Urine,
About Saint Davids day it will go hard with him,
He will then be troubled with a paine in his neck too.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: A peſtilent foole; when wilt thou marry Tony?

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: When I mean to be hangd, & 'tis the ſurer contract.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: What think you of this marriage of Valerios?

sp.speaker: Tony.
sp.p: They have given him a hot cuſtard, and meane to burne his mouth with it; had I knowne he had been given to die honourably, I would have helpt him to a wench, a rare one, ſhould have kill'd him in three weeks, and ſav'd the ſentence.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: There be them would have ſpared ten daies of that too.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: It may be ſo, you have women of all vertues;
There be ſome Guns that I could bring him too,
Some Morter-peeces that are plac'd i'th Suburbs,
Would teare him into quartets in two houres;
There be alſo of the race of the old Cockatrices,
That would diſpatch him with once looking on him.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: What Month wouldſt thou chuſe Tony, if thou hadſt the like fortune?

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.p: I would chuſe a mull'd Sack month, to comfort my belly, for ſure my back would ake for't, and at the months end I would be moſt diſmally drunk, & ſcorn the gallows.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p: I would chuſe March, for I would come in like a Lion.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: But you'ld go out like a Lamb, when you went to hanging.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: I would take April, take the ſweet o'th year,
And kiſſe my wench upon the tender flowrets,
Tumble on every Greene, and as the birds ſung,
Embrace and melt away my ſoule in pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: You would go a Maying gayly to the gallowes.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Prethee tell us ſome newes.

sp.speaker: Tony.
sp.l: Ile tell ye all I know,
You may be honeſt and poore fooles, as I am,
And blow your fingers ends.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: That's no newes foole.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: You may be knaves then, when you pleaſe, ſtarke knaves,
And build faire houſes, but your heires ſhall have none of 'em.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Theſe are undoubted.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: Truth is not worth the hearing,
Ile tell you newes then, There was a drunken Saylor,
That got a Marmaid with childe as ſhe went a milking,
And now ſhe ſues him in the bawdy Court for it,
The infant Monſter is brought up in fiſh-ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I, this is ſomthing.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: Ile tell you more, There was a fiſh taken,
A monſtrous fiſh, with a ſword by his ſide, a long ſword,
A pike in's neck, and a gun in's noſe, a huge gun,
And letters of Mart in's mouth, from the Duke of Florence.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: This is a monſtrous lye.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: I do confeſſe it;
Do you think I would tell you truths, that dare not heare 'em?
You are honeſt things, we Courtiers ſcorn to converſe with Exit.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: A plaguy foole, but lets conſider Gentl.
Why the Queen ſtrives not to oppoſe this ſentence,
The Kingdomes honour ſuffers in this cruelty.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: No doubt the Queen, though ſhe be vertuous,
Winks at the marriage, for by that only meanes
The Kings flame leſſens to the youthfull Lady,
If not goes out, within this month, I doubt not,
She hopes to rock a ſleep his anger alſo;
Shall we go ſee the preparation?
'Tis time, for ſtrangers come to view the wonder.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Come, lets away, ſend my friends happier weddings. Exe.

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.l: You ſhall be merry, come, Ile have it ſo,
Can there be any nature ſo unnoble?
Or anger ſo unhumane to purſue this?

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: I feare there is.

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.l: Your feares are poore and fooliſh,
Though he be haſty, and his anger death,
His will like torrents, not to be reſiſted,
Yet Law and Juſtice go along to guide him;
And what Law or what Juſtice can he finde
To juſtifie his will? what Act or Statute,
By Humane or Divine eſtabliſhment,
Left to direct us, that makes marriage death?
Honeſt faire wedlock? 'twas given for increaſe,
For preſervation of mankinde I take it;
He muſt be more then man then, that dare break it;
Come dreſſe ye handſomly, you ſhall have my Jewels,
And put a face on that contemnes baſe fortune,
'Twill make him more inſult to ſee you fearfull,
Outlooke his anger.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: O my Valerio!
Be witneſſe my pure minde, 'tis thee I grieve for.

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.l: But ſhew it not, I would ſo crucifie him
With an innocent neglect of what he can do,
A brave ſtrong pious ſcorne, that I would ſhake him;
Put all the wanton Cupids in thine eyes,
And all the graces on that nature gave thee,
Make up thy beauty to that height of excellence,
Ile help thee, and forgive thee, as if Venus
Were now againe to catch the God of Warre,
In his moſt rugged anger, when thou haſt him
(As 'tis impoſſible he ſhould reſiſt thee)
And kneeling at thy conquering feet for mercy,
Then ſhew thy vertue, then againe deſpiſe him
And all his power, then with a looke of honour,
Mingled with noble chaſtity, ſtrike him dead.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: Good Madam dreſſe me,
You arme me bravely.

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.l: Make him know his cruelty
Begins with him firſt, he muſt ſuffer for it,
And that thy ſentence is ſo welcome to thee,
And to thy noble Lord, You long to meet it.
Stamp ſuch a deep impreſſion of thy beauty
Into his ſoule, and of thy worthineſſe,
That when Valerio and Evanthe ſleep
In one rich earth, hung round about with bleſſings,
He may run mad, and curſe his act; be luſty,
Ile teach thee how to die too, if thou fear'ſt it.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: I thank your Grace, you have prepar'd me ſtrongly,
And my weak minde.

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.l: Death is unwelcome never,
Unleſſe it be to tortur'd mindes and ſick ſoules,
That make their own Hells; 'tis ſuch a benefit
When it comes crown'd with honour, ſhews ſo ſweet too,
Though they paint it ugly, that's but to reſtraine us,
For every living thing would love it elſe,
Fly boldly to their peace, ere nature call'd 'em;
The reſt we have from labour, and from trouble,
Is ſome incitement, every thing alike,
The poore ſlave that lies private has his liberty,
As amply as his Maſter, in that Tombe,
The earth as light upon him, and the flowers
That grow about him, ſmell as ſweet, and flouriſh,
But when we love with honour to our ends,
When memory and vertues are our mourners,
What pleasure's there? they are infinite Evanthe;
Onely, my vertuous wench, we want our ſences,
That benefit we are barr'd, 'twould make us proud elſe,
And lazy to look up to happier life,
The bleſſings of the people would ſo ſwell us.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Good Madam dreſſe me, you have dreſt my ſoul,
The merrieſt Bride ile be for all this miſery,
The proudeſt to ſome eyes too.

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.l: 'Twill do better, come ſhrink no more.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: I am too confident. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Sora.
sp.l: You are too remiſſe and wanton in your angers,
You mold things hanſomly, and then neglect 'em;
A powerfull Prince ſhould be conſtant to his power ſtill,
And hold up what he builds, then people feare him;
When he lets looſe his hand, it ſhewes a weakneſſe,
And men examine or contemne his greatneſſe;
A ſcorne of this high kinde ſhould have cal'd up
A revenge equall, not a pitty in you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: She is thy ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: And ſhe were my mother,
Whilſt I conceive ſhe has you wrong'd, I hate her,
And ſhake her neerneſſe off; I ſtudy, Sir,
To ſatisfie your angers that are juſt,
Before your pleaſures.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I have done that already,
I feare has pull'd to many curſes on me.

sp.speaker: Sora.
sp.l: Curſes or envies, on Valerio's head,
Would you take my counſell, Sir, they ſhould all light,
And with the weight, not only crack his ſcull,
But his faire credit; the exquiſite vexation
I have devis'd, ſo pleaſe you give way in't,
And let it worke, ſhall more afflict his ſoule,
And trench upon that honour that he brags of,
Then feare or death in all the frights he carries;
If you ſit downe here they will both abuſe ye,
Laugh at your poore relenting powre, and ſcorne ye;
What ſatiſfaction can their deaths bring to you,
That are prepar'd and proud to dye, and willingly,
And at their ends will thank you for that honour?
How are you nearer the deſire you aim at?
Or if it be revenge your anger covets,
How can their ſingle deaths give you content, Sir?
Petty revenges end in blood, ſleight angers,
A Princes rage ſhould finde out new diſeaſes,
Death were a pleaſure too, to pay proud fooles with.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: What ſhould I do?

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Adde but your power unto me,
Make me but ſtrong by your protection,
And you ſhall ſee what joy, and what delight,
What infinite pleaſure this poore mouth ſhall yeeld him,
Ile make him wiſh he were dead on's marriage day,
Or bedrid with old age, ile make him curſe,
And cry and curſe, give me but power.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: You have it,
Here take my Ring, I am content he pay for't.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: It ſhall be now revenge, as I will handle it,
He ſhall live after this to beg his life too,
Twenty to one by this thread, as ile weave it,
Evanthe ſhall be yours.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Take all authority, and be moſt happy.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Good Sir, no more pitty. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Tony, three Citizens, and three Wives.

sp.speaker: 1. Wife.
sp.l: Good Maſter Tony, put me in.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: Where do you dwell?

sp.speaker: 1. Wife.
sp.l: Forſooth, at the ſign of the great ſhoulder of Mutton,

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: A hungry man would hunt your houſe out inſtantly, Keep the dogs from your doore; Is this Lettice Ruffe your husband? a fine ſharp ſallet to your ſigne.

sp.speaker: 2. Wife.
sp.l: Will you put me in too?

sp.speaker: 3. Wife.
sp.l: And me, good Maſter Tony.

sp.speaker: Tony.
sp.l: Put ye all in? you had beſt come twenty more; you
Think 'tis eaſie, a trick of legerdemaine, to put ye all in,
'Twould poſe a fellow that had twice my body,
Though it were all made into chines and fillets.

sp.speaker: 2. W.
sp.l: Puts into'th wedding, Sir, we would fain ſee that.

sp.speaker: 1. W.
sp.l: And the brave Maſque too.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: You two are pretty women, are you their husbands?

sp.speaker: 2. Citiz.
sp.l: Yes, for want of better.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: I think ſo too, you would not be ſo mad elſe
To turne 'em looſe to a company of young Courtiers,
That ſwarme like Bees in May, when they ſee young wenches;
You muſt not ſqueak.

sp.speaker: 3. W.
sp.l: No Sir, we are better tutor'd.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: Nor if a young Lord offer you the curteſie—

sp.speaker: 2. W.
sp.l: We know what 'tis, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: Nor you muſt not grumble,
If you be thruſt up hard, we thruſt moſt furiouſly.

sp.speaker: 1. W.
sp.l: We know the worſt.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: Get you two in then quietly,
And ſhift for your ſelves; we muſt have no old women,
They are out of uſe, unleſſe they have petitions,
Beſides they cough ſo loud they drown the Muſick,
You would go in too, but there is no place for ye,
I am ſorry for't, go and forget your wives,
Or pray they may be able to ſuffer patiently.
You may have Heires may prove wiſe Aldermen,
Go, or ile call the Guard.

sp.speaker: 3 Citi.
sp.l: We will get in, wee'l venture broken pates elſe.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: 'Tis impoſſible,
You are too ſecurely arm'd; how they flock hether,
And with what joy the women run by heapes
To ſee this Marriage? they tickle to think of it,
They hope for every moneth a husband too;
Still how they run, and how the wittals follow 'em,
The weake things that are worne between the leggs,
That bruſhing, dreſſing, nor new naps can mende,
How they poſt to ſee their owne confuſion?
This is a merry world.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Looke to the doore ſirra,
Thou art a foole, and may'ſt do miſchiefe lawfully.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: Give me your hand, you are my brother Foole,
You may both make the Law, and mar it preſently.
Do you love a wench?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Who does not foole?

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.p: Not I, unleſſe you will give me a longer leaſe to marry her.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What are all theſe that come, what buſineſſe have they?

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: Some come to gape, thoſe are my fellow fooles;
Some to get home theit wives, thoſe be their own fooles;
Some to rejoyce with thee, thoſe be the times fooles;
And ſome I feare to curſe thee, thoſe are poore fooles.
sp.stage: Enter Caſſandra, an old Lady paſſing over.
sp.l: A ſet people calls them honeſt. Looke, looke King, look,
A weather-beaten Lady new carin'd.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: An old one.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: The glaſſes of her eyes are new rub'd over,
And the worme-eaten records in her face are daub'd up neatly;
She layes her breaſts out too, like to poch'd eggs
That had the yelkes ſuckt out; they get new heads alſo,
New teeth, new tongues, for the old are all worne-out,
And as 'tis hoped, new tayles.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: For what?

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: For old Courtiers,
The young ones are too ſtirring for their travells.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: God leave your knavery, and helpe to keepe the doore well,
I will have no ſuch preſſe.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: Lay thy hand a thy heart King.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Ile have ye whipt.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: The Foole and thou are parted. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Sorano work, and free me from this ſpell,
'Twixt love and ſcorne there's nothing felt but hell. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Valerio, Camillo, Cleanthes, Menallo, and Servants.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Tye on my Scarfe, you are ſo long about me,
Good my Lords help, give me my other Cloke,
That Hat and Feather, Lord what a Taylor's this,
To make me up thus ſtraight, one ſigh would burſt me,
I have not roome to breath, come button, button,
Button, apace.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I am glad to ſee you merry Sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Twould make you merry had you ſuch a wife,
And ſuch an age to injoy her in.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: An age Sir?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: A moneth's an age to him that is contented,
What ſhould I ſeeke for more? give me my ſword.
Ha my good Lords, that every one of you now
Had but a Lady of that youth and beauty
To bleſſe yourſelves this night with, would ye not?
Pray ye ſpeak uprightly.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: We confeſſe ye happy,
And we could well wiſh ſuch another Banquet,
But on that price my Lord—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Twere nothing elſe,
No man can ever come to aime at Heaven,
But by the knowledge of a Hell. Theſe ſhooes are heavy,
And if I ſhould be call'd to dance they'l clog me,
Get me ſome pumps; ile tell ye brave Camillo,
And you deare friends, the King has honour'd me,
Out of his gracious favour has much honour'd me,
To limit me my time, for who would live long?
Who would be old? 'tis ſuch a wearineſſe,
Such a diſeaſe, that hangs like lead upon us
As it increaſes, ſo vexations,
Griefes of the minde, paines of the feeble body,
Rhumes, coughs, catarrs, we are but our living coffines;
Beſide, the faire ſoules old too, it growes covetous,
Which ſhewes all honour is departed from us,
And we are earth againe.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: You make faire uſe Sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I would not live to learne to lye Cleanthes
For all the world, old men are prone to that too;
Thou that haſt been a Souldier, Menallo
A noble Souldier, and defied all danger,
Adopted thy brave arme the heire to victory,
Would'ſt thou live ſo long till thy ſtrength forſooke thee?
Till thou grew'ſt only a long tedious ſtory
Of what thou hadſt been? till thy ſword hang by,
And lazie Spiders fill'd the hilt with cobwebs?

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.l: No ſure, I would not.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Tis not fit ye ſhould,
To dye a young man is to be an Angell,
Our great good parts, put wings to our ſoules:
Wee'l have a rouſe before we go to bed friends,
Pray ye tell me, iſt a hanſome Maske we have?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: We underſtand ſo.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And the young gent. dance?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: They do Sir, and ſome dance well.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: They muſt before the Ladies,
Wee'l have a rouſe before we go to bed friends,
A luſty one, 'twill make my blood dance too. Muſick

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Ten if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And wee'l be wondrous merry,
They ſtay ſure, come, I heare the Muſick forward,
You ſhall have all Gloves preſently. Exit.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: We attend Sir, but firſt we muſt looke to'th
Doores. Knocking within.
The King has charged us. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: 1 Serv.
sp.l: What a noyſe do you keepe there, call my fellowes
A the Guard; you muſt ceaſe now untill the King be
Enter'd, he is gone to'th Temple now.

sp.speaker: 2 Serv.
sp.l: Looke to that back doore, and keep it faſt,
They ſwarme like Bees about it,

div.stage: Enter Camillo, Cleanthes, Menallo, Tony following, and Foole following.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Keepe back thoſe Citizens, and let their wives in,
Their hanſome wives.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: They have crowded me to Vergis,
I ſweat like a Butter-box.

sp.speaker: 1 Serv.
sp.l: Stand further off there.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Take the women aſide, and talk with 'em in privat,
Give 'em that they came for.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: The whole Court cannot do it;
Beſides, the next Maske if we uſe 'em ſo,
They'l come by millions to expect our largeſſe;
We have broke a hundred heads.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Are they ſo tender?

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: But 'twas behinde, before they have all murrions.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Let in thoſe Ladies, make 'em roome for ſhame there.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: They are no Ladies, there's one bald before 'em,
A gent. bald, they are curtall'd queanes in hired clothes,
They come out of Spaine I think, they are very ſultry.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Keep 'em in breath for an Embaſſadour.
Me thinks my noſe ſhakes at their memories,
What bounſing's that?

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: I am one of the Muſick Sir.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: I have ſweet-meats for the banquet.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Let 'em in.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: They lye my Lord, they come to ſeeke their wives,
Two broken Citizens.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Breake 'em more, they are but bruſled yet.
Bold Raſcalls, offer to diſturbe your wives.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Lock the doores faſt; the Muſick, hark, the King comes.

div.stage: The King, Queene, Valerio, Evanthe, Ladies, Attendants, Ca|millo, Cleanthes, Sorano, Menallo.

body.head: A Maske.
body.stage: Cupid deſcends, the Graces ſitting by him, Cupid being bound the Graces unbinde him, he ſpeakes.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.l: Unbinde me, my delight, this night is mine,
Now let me looke upon what Stars here ſhine,
Let me behold the beauties, then clap high
My cullor'd wings, proud of my Deity;
I am ſatisfied, binde me agen, and faſt,
My angry Bow will make too great a waſte
Of beauty elſe, now call my Maskers in,
Call with a Song, and let the ſports begin;
Call all my ſervants the effects of love,
And to a meaſure let them nobly move.
Come you ſervants of proud love,
Come away:
Fairely, nobly, gently move,
Too long, too long you make us ſtay;
Fancy, Deſire, Delight, Hope, Feare,
Diſtruſt and Jealouſie, be you too here;
Conſuming Care, and raging Ire,
And Poverty in poore attire,
March fairely in, and laſt Deſpaire;
Now full Muſick ſtrike the Aire.

body.stage: Enter the Maskers, Fancy, Deſire, Delight, Hope, Feare, Diſtruſt, Jealouſie, Care, Ire, Deſpaire, they dance, after which Cupid ſpeakes.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.l: Away, I have done, the day begins to light,
Lovers, you know your fate, good night, good night.

body.stage: Cupid and the Graces aſcend in the Chariot.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Come to the Banquet, when that's ended Sir,
Ile ſee you a bed, and ſo good night; be merry,
You have a ſweet bed-fellow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I thanke your Grace,
And ever ſhall be bound unto your nobleneſſe.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I pray I may deſerve your thankes, ſet forward.

div.head: Scaena Prima.
div.stage: Enter divers Monkes, Alphonſo going to the Tombe, Rugio and Frier Marco diſcover the Tombe and a Chaire.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: THe night growes on, lead ſoftly to the Tombe,
And ſing not till I bid ye; let the Muſick
Play gently as he paſſes.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: O faire picture,
That wert the living hope of all our honours;
How are we baniſht from the joy we dreamt of?
Will he ne're ſpeak more?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis full three moneths Lord Rugio,
Since any articulate ſound came from his tongue,
Set him downe gently. Sits in Chaire.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: What ſhould the reaſon be Sir?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: As 'tis in nature with thoſe loving Husbands,
That ſympathize their wives paines, and their throwes
When they are breeding, and 'tis uſuall too,
We have it by experience ſo in him Sir,
In this moſt noble ſpirit that now ſuffers;
For when his honour'd Father good Brandino
Fell ſick, he felt the griefes, and labour'd with them,
His ſits and his diſeaſe he ſtill inherited,
Grew the ſame thing, and had not nature check'd him,
Strength, and ability, he had dyed that houre too.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: Embleme of noble love!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That very minute
His fathers breath forſooke him, that ſame inſtant,
A rare example of his piety,
And love paternall, the Organ of his tongue
Was never heard to ſound againe; ſo neare death
He ſeekes to waite upon his worthy Father,
But that we force his meat, he were one body.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: He points toth' Tombe.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That is the place he honours,
A houſe I feare he will not be long out of.
He will toth' Tombe, good my Lord lend your hand;
Now ſing the Funerall Song, and let him kneele,
For then he is pleas'd. A Song.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: Heaven lend thy powerfull hand,
And eaſe this Prince.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He will paſſe back againe. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: They drink abundantly, I am hot with wine too,
Luſtily warme, ile ſteale now to my happineſſe,
'Tis midnight, and the ſilent houre invites me,
But ſhe is up ſtill, and attends the Queene;
Thou dew of wine and ſleep hang on their eye-lids,
Steep their dull ſences in the healths they drink,
That I may quickly finde my lov'd Evanthe.
The King is merry too, and dranke unto me,
Signe affaire peace, O this nights bleſſedneſſe!
If I had forty heads I would give all for it.
Is not the end of our ambitions,
Of all our humane ſtudies, and our travells,
Of our deſires, the obtaining of our wiſhes?
Certaine it is, and there man makes his Center.
I have obtain'd Enanthe, I have married her,
Can any fortune keep me from injoying her?
I have my wiſh, what's left me to accuſe now?
I am friends with all the world, but thy baſe malice;
Go glory in thy miſchiefes thou proud man,
And cry it to the world thou haſt ruin'd vertue;
How I contemne thee and thy petty malice,
And with what ſcorne I looke downe on thy practice.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: You'l ſing me a new Song anon Ʋalerio,
And wiſh theſe hot words—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I deſpiſe thee fellow,
Thy threats, or flatteries, all I fling behinde me;
I have my end, I have thy noble Siſter,
A name too worthy of thy blood; I have married her,
And will injoy her too.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: 'Tis very likely.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And that ſhort moneth I have to bleſſe me with her
Ile make an age, ile reckon each embrace
A yeare of pleaſure, and each night a Jubilee,
Every quick kiſſe a Spring; and when I meane
To loſe my ſelfe in all the delightfulneſſe,
Twenty ſweet Summers I will tye together
In ſpight of thee, and thy malignant Maſter:
I will dye old in love, though young in pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: But that I hate thee deadly, I could pitty thee,
Thou art the pooreſt miſerable thing
This day on earth; ile tell thee why Valerio,
All thou eſteemeſt, and build'ſt upon for happineſſe,
For joy, for pleaſure, for delight is paſt thee,
And like a wanton dreame already vaniſht.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Is my love falſe?

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: No, ſhe is conſtant to thee,
Conſtant to all thy miſery ſhe ſhall be,
And curſe thee too.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Is my ſtrong body weakn'd,
Charm'd, or abus'd with ſubtle drink? ſpeak villaine.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Neither, I dare ſpeake, thou art ſtill as luſty
As when thou lovsdſt her firſt, as ſtrong and hopefull,
The month thou haſt given thee is a month of miſery,
And where thou think'ſt each hower ſhall yeeld a pleaſure
Looke for a killing paine, for thou ſhalt finde it
Before thou dyeſt, each minute ſhall prepare it,
And ring ſo many knells to ſad afflictions;
The King has given thee a long moneth to dye in,
And miſerably dye.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Undo thy Riddle,
I am prepar'd what ever fate ſhall follow.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Doſt thou ſee this Ring?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I know it too.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Then marke me,
By vertue of this Ring this I pronounce to thee,
'Tis the Kings will.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Let me know it ſuddenly.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: If thou doſt offer to touch Evanthes body
Beyond a kiſſe, though thou art married to her,
And lawfully as thou think'ſt may'ſt injoy her,
That minute ſhe ſhall dye.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O Devill—

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: If thou diſcover this command unto her,
Or to a friend that ſhall importune thee,
And why thou abſtaineſt, and from whoſe will, ye all periſh,
Upon the ſelf-ſame forfeit are ye fitted Sir,
Now if ye love her, ye may preſerve her life ſtill,
If not, you know the worſt, how falls your month out?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: This tyranny could never be invented
But in the ſchoole of Hell, earth is too innocent;
Not to injoy her when ſhe is my wife?
When ſhe is willing too?

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: She is moſt willing,
And will run mad to miſſe; but if you hit her,
Be ſure you bit her home, and kill her with it;
There are ſuch women that will dye with pleaſure:
The Axe will follow elſe, that will not faile
To fetch her Maiden-head, and diſpatch her quickly;
Then ſhall the world know you are the cauſe of Murther,
And as 'tis requiſite your life ſhall pay for't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Thou doſt but jeſt, thou canſt not be ſo mooſtrous
As thou proclaim'ſt thy ſelfe; thou art her Brother,
and there muſt be a feeling heart within thee
Of her afflictions; wert thou a ſtranger to us,
And bred amongſt wilde rocks, thy nature wilde too,
Affection in thee as thy breeding, cold,
And unrelenting as the rocks that nouriſht thee,
Yet thou muſt ſhake to tell me this; they tremble
When the rude ſea threatens divorce amongſt 'em,
They that are ſenceleſſe things ſhake at a tempeſt;
Thou art a man—

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Be thou too then, 'twill try thee,
And patience now will beſt become thy nobleneſſe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Invent ſome other torment to afflict me,
All, if thou pleaſe, put all afflictions on me,
Study thy braines out for 'em, ſo this be none
I care not of what nature, nor what cruelty,
Nor of what length.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: This is enough to vex ye.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: The tale of Tantalus is now prov'd true,
And from me ſhall be regiſtred Authentick;
To have my joyes within my armes, and lawfull,
Mine owne delights, yet dare not touch.
Even as thou hateſt me Brother, let no young man know this,
As thou ſhalt hope for peace when thou moſt needeſt it,
Peace in thy ſoule, deſire the King to kill me,
Make me a traitor, any thing, ile yeeld to it,
And give thee cauſe ſo I may dye immediatly;
Lock me in Priſon where no Sun may ſee me,
In walls ſo thick no hope may ere come at me;
Keep me from meat, and drink, and ſleep, ile bleſſe thee;
Give me ſome damned potion to deliver me,
That I may never know my ſelfe againe, forget
My Country kindred, name and fortune; laſt,
That my chaſte love may never appeare before me,
This were ſome comfort.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: All I have I have brought ye,
And much may it do ye with it my deare Brother,
See ye obſerve it well; you will finde about ye
Many eyes ſet, that ſhall o're-looke your actions,
If you tranſgreſſe ye know, and ſo I leave ye,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Heaven be not angry, and I have ſome hope yet,
And when you pleaſe, and how allay my miſeries.
To whom I kneele be mercifull unto me,
Looke on my harmeleſſe youth Angels of pitty,
And from my bleeding heart wipe off my ſorrowes,
The power, the pride, the malice and injuſtice
Of cruell men are bent againſt mine innocence.
You that controwle the mighty wills of Princes,
And bow their ſtubborne armrs, look on my weakneſſe,
And when you pleaſe, and how, allay my miſeries. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Haſt thou been with him?

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Yes, and given him that Sir
Will make him curſe his Birth; I told ye which way,
Did you but ſee him Sir, but look upon him,
With what a troubled and dejected nature
He walkes now in a miſt, with what a ſilence,
As if he were the ſhrowd he wrapt himſelfe in,
And no more of Valerio but his ſhadow,
He ſeekes obſcurity to hide his thoughts in,
You would wonder and admire for all you know it,
His jollity is downe, valed to the ground Sir,
And his high hopes of full delights and pleaſures
Are turn'd tormenters to him, ſtrong diſeaſes.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: But is there hope of her?

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: It muſt fall neceſſary
She muſt diſlike him, quarrell with his perſon,
For women once deluded are next Devills,
And in the height of that opinion Sir,
You ſhall put on againe, and ſhe muſt meet ye,

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I am glad of this.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Ile tell ye all the circumſtance
Within this houre, but ſure I heard your Grace
To day as I attended, make ſome ſtops,
Some broken ſpeeches, and ſome fighs between,
And then your Brothers name I heard diſtinctly,
And ſome ſad wiſhes after.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Ye are i'th right Sir,
I would he were as ſad as I could wiſh him,
Sad as the earth.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Would ye have it ſo?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Thou heareſt me,
Though he be ſick with ſmall hope of recovery,
That hope ſtill lives, and mens eyes live upon it,
And in their eyes their wiſhes; my Soram,
Were he but cold once in the tombe he dotes on,
As 'tis the fitteſt place for melancholly,
My Court ſhould be another Paradice,
And flow with all delights.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Go to your pleaſures, let me alone with this,
Hope ſhall not trouble ye, nor he three dayes.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I ſhall be bound unto thee.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Ile do it neatly too, no doubt ſhall catch me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Be gone, they are going to bed, ile bid good night to 'em.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.p: And mark the man, you'le ſcarce know 'tis Valerio.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Cheere up my noble Lord, the minutes Come,
You ſhall injoy the abſtract of all ſweetneſſe,
We did you wrong you need no wine to warme ye,
Deſire ſhoots through your eyes like ſudden wild-fires.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Beſhrew me Lo●ds, the wine has made me dull,
I am I know not what.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Good pleaſure to ye,
Good night and long too, as you finde your appetite
Yon may fall too.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I do beſeech your Grace,
For which of all my loves and ſervices
Have I deſerved this:

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I am not bound to anſwer ye.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Nor I bound to obey in unjuſt actions.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Do as you pleaſe, you know the penalty,
And as I have a ſoule it ſhall be executed;
Nay look not pale, I am not uſed to feare Sir,
If you reſpect your Lady, good night to ye. Exit.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But for reſpect to her and to my duty,
That reverent duty that I owe my Soveraigne,
Which anger has no power to ſnatch me from,
The good night ſhould be thine; good night for ever,
The King is wanton Lords, he would needs know of me
How many nick chaſes I would make to night.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: My Lord, no doubt you'l prove a perfect gameſter.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Faith no, I am unacquainted with the pleaſure,
Bungle a ſet I may, how my heart trembles,
And beats my breaſt as it would breake his way out
Good night my noble friends.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Nay we muſt ſee you toward your bed my Lord:

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Good faith it needs not,
'Tis late, and I ſhall trouble you.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: No, no, till the Bride come Sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I beſeech you leave me,
You will make me baſhfull elſe, I am ſo fooliſh,
Beſides, I have ſome few devotions Lords,
And he that can pray with ſuch a book in's armes —

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Wee'l leave ye then, and a ſweet night wait upon ye.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: And a ſweet iſſue of this ſweet night crown ye.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: All nights and dayes be ſuch till you grow old Sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I thank ye, 'tis a curſe ſufficient for me,
A labour'd one too, though you meane a bleſſing.
What ſhall I do, I am like a wretched Debtor,
That has a ſumme to tender on the forfeit
Of all he is worth, yet dare not offer it.
Other men ſee the Sun, yet I muſt wink at it;
And though I know 'tis perfect day, deny it:
My veines are all on fire, and burne like Aetna,
Youth and deſire beat larums to my blood,
And adde freſh fuell to my warme affections.
I muſt injoy her, yet when I conſider,
When I collect my ſelfe, and weigh her danger,
The Tyrants will, and his powre taught to murther,
My tender care controlls my blood within me,
And like a cold fit of a peeviſh Ague
Creepes to my ſoule, and flings an Ice upon me.
sp.stage: Enter Queene, Evanthe, Ladies, and Foole.
sp.l: That locks all powres of youth up but prevention;
O what a bleſſedneſſe 'twere to be old now,
To be unable, bed-rid with diſeaſes,
Or halt on Crutches to meet holy Hymen;
What a rare benefit, but I'am curſt
That that ſpeakes other men moſt freely happy,
And makes all eyes hang on their expectations,
Muſt prove the bane of me youth, and ability.
She comes to bed, how ſhall I entertaine her?

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: Nay I come after too, take the foole with ye,
For lightly he is ever one at Weddings.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Evanthe, make ye unready, our Lord ſtaies for ye,
And prethee be merry.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: Be very merry, Chicken,
Thy Lord will pipe to thee anon, and make thee dance too.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Will he ſo, good-man aſſe.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: Yes goody filly,
And you had ſuch a Pipe, that piped ſo ſweetly,
You would dance to death, you have learnt your ſinque a pace.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Your Grace deſires that that is too free in me,
I am merry at the heart.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.p: Thou wilt be anon, the young ſmug Boy will give thee a ſweet cordiall.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: I am ſo taken up in all my thoughts,
So poſſeſt Madam with the lawfull ſweets
I ſhall this night partake of with my Lord,
So far tranſported (pardon my immmodeſty)

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Alas poore wench, how ſhall I recompence thee?

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: That though they muſt be ſhort, and ſnatcht away too,
E're they grow ripe, yet I ſhall far prefer 'em
Before a tedious pleaſure with repentance.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O how my heart akes.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Take off my Jewells Ladies,
And let my Ruffe looſe, I ſhall bid good night to ye,
My Lord ſtaies here.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: My wench, I thank thee heartily,
For learning how to uſe thy few houres hanſomly,
They will be yeares I hope; off with your Gowne now,
Lay downe the bed there?

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: Shall I get into it and warme it for thee, a Fooles fire is a fine thing,
And I'll ſo buſſe thee.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Ile have ye whipt ye raſcall.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: That will provoke me more, ile talke with thy husband,
He's a wiſe man I hope.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Good night deare Madam,
Ladies, no further ſervice, I am well,
I do beſeech your Grace to give us this leave,
My Lord and I to one another freely,
And privately, may do all other Ceremonies,
Women and Page wee'l be to one another,
And trouble you no farther.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: Art thou a wiſe man?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I cannot tell thee Tony, aske my neighbours.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: If thou beeſt ſo, go lye with me to night,
The old foole will lye quieter then the young one,
And give thee more ſleep, thou wilt looke to morrow elſe
Worſe then the prodigall foole the Ballad ſpeakes of,
That was ſqeez'd through a horne.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I ſhall take thy counſell.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Why then good night, good night my beſt Evanthe,
My worthy maid, and as that name ſhall vaniſh,
A worthy wife, a long and happy; follow ſirra.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: That ſhall be my care,
Goodneſſe reſt with your Grace.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Be luſty Lord, and take your Lady to ye,
And that power that ſhall part ye be unhappy.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sweet reſt unto ye, to ye all ſweet Ladies;
Tony good night.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: Shall not the Foole ſtay with thee?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Come away Sirra. Exeunt Queene, Ladies.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.l: How the Foole is ſought for, ſweet Malt is made of eaſie fire,
A haſty horſe will quickly tire, a ſudden leaper ſticks i'th mire,
Phlebotomy and the word lye nier, take heed of friend I thee require;
This from an Almanack I ſtole, and learnt this Leſſon from a foole.
Good night my Bird. Exit Tony

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Good night wiſe Maſter Tony;
Will ye to bed my Lord? Come, let me help ye.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: To bed Evanthe, art thou ſleepy?

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: No, I ſhall be worſe if you look ſad upon me,
Pray ye let's to bed.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I am not well my love.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Ile make ye well, there's no ſuch Phiſick for ye
As your warme Miſtris armes.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Art thou ſo cunning?

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: I ſpeake not by experience, pray ye miſtake not;
But if you love me—

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: I do love ſo dearely,
So much above the baſe bent of deſire
I know not how to anſwer thee.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: To bed then,
There I ſhall better credit yea; ſie my Lord,
Will ye put a maid too't, to teach ye what to do?
An innocent maid? Are ye ſo cold a Lover?
Intruth you make me bluſh, 'tis midnight too,
And 'tis no ſtolne love, but authoriſed openly,
No ſin we covet, pray let me undreſſe ye,
You ſhall help me; prethee ſweet Valerio;
Be not ſo ſad, the King will be more mercifull.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: May not I love thy minde?

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: And I yours too,
'Tis a moſt noble one, adorn'd with vertue;
But if we love not one another really,
And put our bodies and our mindes together,
And ſo make up the concord of affection,
Our love will prove but a blinde ſuperſtition:
This is no ſchoole to argue in my Lord,
Nor have we time to talke away allow'd us,
Pray let's diſpatch, if any one ſhould come
And finde us at this diſtance, what would they think?
Come, kiſſe me and to bed.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: That I dare do, and kiſſe againe.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Spare not, they are your owne Sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But to injoy thee is to be luxurious,
Too ſenſuall in my love, and too ambitious;
O how I burne! to pluck thee from the ſtalke,
Where now thou grow'ſt a ſweet bud and a beauteous,
And bear'ſt the prime and honour of the Garden,
Is but to violate thy ſpring, and ſpoile thee.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: To let me blow, and fall alone would anger ye.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Let's ſit together thus, and as we ſit
Feed on the ſweets of one anothers ſoules,
The happineſſe of love is contemplation,
The bleſſedneſſe of love is pure affection,
Where no allay of actuall dull deſire,
Of pleaſure that partakes with wantonneſſe,
Of humane fire that burnes out as it kindles,
And leaves the body but a poore repentance,
Can ever mix, let's ſixe on that Evanthe,
That's everlaſting, the tother caſuall;
Eternity breeds one, the other Fortune,
Blinde as her ſelfe, and full of all afflictions.
Shall we love vertuouſly?

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: I ever loved ſo.

sp.speaker: Val
sp.l: And only think our love; the rareſt pleaſure,
And that we moſt deſire, let it be humane,
If once injoyed growes ſtale, and cloyes our appetites;
I would not leſſen in my love for any thing,
Nor finde thee but the ſame in my ſhort journey,
For my loves ſafety.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Now I ſee I am old Sir,
Old and ill-favour'd too, poore and deſpiſ'd,
And am not worth your noble Fellowſhip,
Your fellowſhip in Love, you would not elſe
Thus cunningly ſeeke to betray a maid,
A maid that honours you thus piouſly;
Strive to abuſe the pious love ſhe brings ye.
Farewell my Lord, ſince ye have a better Miſtris,
For it muſt ſeeme ſo, or ye are no man,
A younger, happier, I ſhall give her roome,
So much I love ye ſtill.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Stay my Evanthe;
Heaven beare me witneſſe, thou art all I love,
All I deſire, and now have pitty on me,
I never lyed before; forgive me Juſtice,
Youth and affection ſtop your eares unto me.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Why do you weep? if I have ſpoke too harſhly,
And unbeſeeming my beloved Lord,
My care and duty, pardon me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O heare me,
Heare me Evanthe; I am all on torture
And this lye tears my conſcience as I vent it;
I am no man.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: How Sir?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No man for pleaſure, no womans man,

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.p: Goodneſſe forbid my Lord, ſure you abuſe your ſelfe:

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Tis true Evanthe;
I ſhame to ſay you will finde it. Weepes.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: He weepes bitterly,
'Tis my hard fortune, bleſſe all young maids from it;
Is there no help my Lord in Art will comfort ye?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I hope there is.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: How long have you been deſtitute?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Since I was young.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: 'Tis hard to dye for nothing,
Now you ſhall know 'tis not the pleaſure Sir,
(For I am compell'd to love you ſpiritually)
That women aime at I affect ye for,
'Tis for your worth; and kiſſe me, be at peace,
Becauſe I ever loved ye I ſtill honour'd ye,
And with all duty to my Husband follow ye;
Will ye to bed now? ye are aſham'd it ſeemes;
Pigmalion prayed and his cold ſtone took life,
You do not know with what zeale I ſhall aske Sir,
And what rare miracle that may worke upon ye;
Still bluſh? preſcribe your Law.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I prethee pardon me,
To bed, and ile ſit by thee, and mourne with thee,
Mourne both our fortunes, our unhappy ones:
Do not deſpiſe me, make me not more wretched,
I pray to heaven when I am gone Evanthe,
As my poore date is but a ſpan of time now,
To recompence thy noble patience,
Thy love and vertue with a fruitfull husband,
Honeſt and honourable.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Come, you have made me weep now,
All fond deſire dye here, and welcome chaſtity,
Honour and chaſtity, do what you pleaſe Sir. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Prima.
div.stage: Enter at one doore Rugio, and Frier Marco, at the other doore Sorano, with a little glaſſe violl.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: WHat ailes this peece of miſchief to looke ſad?
He ſeemes to weep too.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Something is a hatching,
And of ſome bloody nature too Lord Rugio,
This Crocadile mournes thus cunningly.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Haile holy Father,
And good day to the good Lord Rugio,
How fares the ſad Prince I beſeech ye Sir?

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: 'Tis like you know, you need not aske that queſtion,
You have your eyes and watches on his miſeries
As neare as ours, I would they were as tender.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Can you do him good? as the King and you appointed him,
So he is ſtill, as you deſir'd I think too,
For every day he is worſe (Heaven pardon all)
Put off your ſorrow, you may laugh now Lord,
He cannot laſt long to diſturbe your Maſter,
You have done worthy ſervice to his Brother,
And he moſt memorable love.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: You do not know Sir
With what remorſe I aske, nor with what wearineſſe
I grone and bow under this load of honour,
And how my ſoule ſighs for the beaſtly ſervices,
I have done his pleaſures, theſe be witneſſe with me,
And from your piety beleeve me Father,
I would as willingly unclothe my ſelfe
Of title, that becomes me not I know;
Good men, and great names beſt agree together;
Caſt off the glorious favours, and the trappings
Of ſound and honour, wealth and promiſes,
His wanton pleaſures have flung on my weakneſſe,
And chuſe to ſerve my Countries cauſe and vertues,
Poorely and honeſtly, and redeeme my rulnes,
As I would hope remiſſion of my miſchiefes.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: Old and experienc'd men my Lord Sorano,
Are not ſo quickly caught with gilt hypocriſie,
You pull your clawes in now and fawne upon us,
As Lyons do to intice poore fooliſh beaſts;
And beaſts we ſhould be too if we beleeved ye,
Go exerciſe your Art.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: For heaven ſake ſcorne me not,
Nor adde more hell to my afflicted ſoule
Then I feele here; as you are honourable,
As you are charitable looke gently on me,
I will no more to Court, be no more Devill.
I know I muſt be hated even of him
That was my Love now, and the more he loves me
For his foule ends, when they ſhall once appeare to him,
Muſter before his conſcience and accuſe him,
The fouler and the more falls his diſpleaſure,
Princes are fading things, ſo are their favours.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He weeps agen, his heart is toucht ſure with remorce.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: See this, and give me faire attention good my Lord,
And worthy Father ſee, within this violl
The remedy and cure of all my honour,
And of the ſad Prince lyes.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: What new trick's this?

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: 'Tis true, I have done Offices abundantly
Ill, and prodigious to the Prince Alphonſo,
And whilſt I was a knave I ſought his death too.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: You are too late convicted to be good yet.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: But Father, when I felt this part afflict me,
This inward, and call'd me to an audit
Of my miſdeeds and miſchiefes—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Well, go on Sir.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: O then, then, then, what was my glory then Father?
The favour of the King, what did that eaſe me?
What was it to be bow'd to by all creatures?
Worſhipt, and courted, what did this availe me?
I was a wretch, a poore loſt wretch.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Still better.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Till in the midſt of all my griefe I found
Repentance, and a learned man to give the meanes to it,
A Jew, an honeſt and a rare Phiſition,
Of him I had this Jewell; 'tis a Jewell,
And at the price of all my wealth I bought it:
If the King knew it I muſt loſe my head,
And willingly, moſt willingly I would ſuffer,
A childe may take it, 'tis ſo ſweet in working.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: To whom would you apply it too?

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: To the ſick Prince,
It will in halfe a day diſſolve his melancholly.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: I do beleeve, and give him ſleep for ever.
What impudence is this, and what baſe malice,
To make us inſtruments of thy abuſes?
Are we ſet here to poiſon him?

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Miſtake not, yet I muſt needs ſay, 'tis a noble care,
And worthy vertuous ſervants; if you will ſee
A flouriſhing eſtate againe in Naples,
And great Alphonſo reigne that's truly good,
And like himſelfe able to make all excellent;
Give him this drink, & this good health unto him. Drinks
I am not ſo deſperate yet to kill my ſelfe,
Never looke on me as a guilty man,
Nor on the water as a ſpeedy poiſon:
I am not mad, nor laid out all my treaſure,
My conſcience and my credit to abuſe ye;
How nimbly and how cheerefully it workes now
Upon my heart and head, ſure I am a new man
There is no ſadneſſe that I feele within me,
But as it meets it like a lazie vapour
How it flyes off. Here, give it him with ſpeed,
You are more guilty then I ever was,
And worthier of the name of evill ſubjects:
If but an houre you hold this from his health.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.l: 'Tis ſome rare vertuous thing ſure, he is a good man,
It muſt be ſo, come, let's apply it preſently,
And may it ſweetly work.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Pray let me heare on't, and carry it cloſe my Lords.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes, good Sorano. Exit Rugio, Marco.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Do my good fooles, my honeſt pious coxcombs,
My wary fooles too, have I caught your wiſedomes,
You never dream't I knew an Antidote,
Nor how to take it to ſecure mine owne life;
I am an aſſe, go, give him the fine cordiall,
And when you have done go dig his grave, good Frier,
Some two houres hence we ſhall have ſuch a bawling,
And roaring up and downe for Aquavitae,
Such rubbing, and ſuch nointing, and ſuch cooling,
I have ſent him that will make a bonefire in's belly,
If he recover it, there is no heat in Hell ſure. Exit.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Call hither Lord Valerio, and let none trouble us.

sp.speaker: Pod.
sp.l: It ſhall be done Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I know he wants no additions to his tortures,
He has enough for humane blood to carry,
Yet I muſt vex him further;
So many that I wonder his hot youth
And high-bred ſpirit breakes not into fury;
I muſt yet torture him a little further,
And make my ſelfe ſport with his miſeries,
My anger is too poore elſe. Here he comes, Valerio.
Now my young married Lord, how do you feele your ſelf?
You have the happineſſe you ever aimed at
The joy and pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Would you had the like Sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: You tumble in delights with your ſweet Lady,
And draw the minutes out in deare embraces,
You live a right Lords life.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Would you had tryed it,
That you might know the vertue but to ſuffer,
Your anger though it be unjuſt and inſolent,
Sits hanſomer upon you then your ſcorne,
To do a wilfull ill and glory in it,
Is to do it double, double to be damn'd too.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Haſt thou not found a loving and free Prince,
High in his favours too; that has confer'd
Such hearts eaſe, and ſuch heapes of comfort on thee,
All thou coudeſt aske.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You are too growne a tyrant
Upon ſo ſuffering, and ſo ſtill a ſubject;
You have put upon me ſuch a puniſhment,
That if your youth were honeſt it would bluſh at:
But you are a ſhame to nature, as to vertue.
Pull not my rage upon ye, 'tis ſo juſt,
It will give way to no reſpect; my life,
My innocent life, I dare maintaine it Sir,
Like a wanton prodigall you have flung away,
Had I a thouſand more I would allow 'em,
And be as careleſſe of 'em as your will is;
But to deny thoſe rights the Law has given me,
The holy Law, and make her life the pennance,
Is ſuch a ſtudied and unheard of malice,
No heart that is not hyred from Hell dare think of;
To do it then too, when my hopes were high,
High as my blood, all my deſires upon me,
My free affections ready to embrace her,
And ſhe mine owne; do you ſmile at this, iſt done well?
Is there not heaven above you that ſees all?
Come hither Time, how does your noble Miſtris?

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.l: As a Gentlewoman may do in her caſe that's newly married Sir:
Sickly ſometimes, and fond on't, like your Majeſty.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: She is breeding then?

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.l: She wants much of her cullour,
And has her qualmes as Ladies uſe to have Sir,
And her diſguſts.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: And keeps her chamber?

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.l: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: And eats good Brooths and Jellies.

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.l: I am ſure ſhe ſighs Sir, and weepes, good Lady.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Alas good Lady for it,
She ſhould have one could comfort her Caſſandra,
Could turne thoſe teares to joyes, a luſty comforter.

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.l: A comfortable man does well at all houres,
For he brings comfortable things.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Come hither, & hold your face between, you have eaten Onions,
Her breath ſtinks like a Fox, her teeth are contagious,
Theſe old women are all Elder-pipes, do ye mark me.

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.l: Yes Sir, but does your Grace think I am fit,
That am both old and vertuous.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Therefore the fitter, the older ſtill the better,
I know thou art as holy as an old Cope,
Yet upon neceſſary uſe.

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.l: 'Tis true Sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Her feeling ſence is fierce ſtill, ſpeake unto her,
You are familiar; ſpeake I ſay unto her,
Speake to the purpoſe; tell her this, and this.

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.l: Alas, ſhe is honeſt, Sir, ſhe is very honeſt,
And would you have my gravity—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I, I, your gravity will become the cauſe the better,
Ile looke thee out a Knight ſhall make thee a Lady too,
A luſt Knight, and one that ſhall be ruled by her;
And adde to theſe, ile make 'em good, no mincing,
Nor ducking out of nicity good Lady,
But do it home, wee'l all be friends to tell her;
And ſuch a joy—

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.l: That's It that ſtirs me up Sir,
I would not for the world attempt her chaſtity,
But that they may live lovingly hereafter.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: For that I urge it too.

sp.speaker: Caſs.
sp.l: A little evill may well be ſuffered for a generall good, Sir,
Ile take my leave of your Majeſty. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Go fortunately, be ſpeedy too, here comes Valerio,
If his affliction have allayed his ſpirit
My work has end. Come hither Lord Valerio,
How do you now?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Your Majeſty may gheſſe,
Not ſo well, nor ſo fortunate as you are,
That can tye up mens honeſt wills and actions.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: You have the happineſſe you ever aim'd at,
The joy, and pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Would you had the like Sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: You tumble in delights with your ſweet Lady,
